newsitem.title: CHILE: Endesa to link Atacama gas to Chile grid.
newsitem.headline: Endesa to link Atacama gas to Chile grid.

text.p: Power generator Endesa plans to connect the Atacama natural gas pipeline from Argentina to Chile's main electricity grid with a new pipeline, power plants and transmission wires in northern Chile, the company said Thursday.

The $145 million project will boost the energy flow onto the central grid, which supplies about 80 percent of Chilean electricity consumption. In a statement, Endesa said it will build a 260 km natural gas pipeline from the port of Mejillones, where the Atacama pipeline will have its outlet, south to the town of Taltal.

In Taltal, the company will build two natgas-fired power plants, the first of which will have a power capacity of 175 megawatts and come on line in the first half of 1999. It gave no details on the second plant.

New 220-kilovolt transmission lines, about 170 km long, will then connect the Taltal power plants to an existing substation at Diego de Almagro, the northern terminus of the central power grid known by its Spanish acronym as the SIC.

The project will create "a link between the two systems," said Endesa. "The Taltal project is aimed at supplying the high growth rate in electric energy demand expected in the coming years in the northern area of SIC."

Endesa will create two new subsidiary companies with the project, one for the Mejillones-Taltal natgas pipeline and one for the power plants. It offered CMS Energy Corp, its partner in building the Atacama natgas pipeline, an option to join both companies, Endesa said.

The Mejillones-Taltal pipeline will also supply natural gas for the city of Antofagasta, the regional capital, and nearby industrial clients. Several major copper mines, including Escondida and Mantos Blancos, have mines or processing plants in the immediate area.
Endesa and CMS are 50-50 partners in building the $650 million Atacama pipeline to bring natgas from northwestern Argentina and supply energy to Chile's fast-growing copper industry.
The pipeline, one of two major natgas ducts being built over the Andes from Argentina, is due to come onstream in early 1999 with the building of two 355 megawatt power plants in northern Chile.

Endesa and CMS announced last month that they awarded contracts for the construction of the two 355 megawatt power plants to GEC-Alsthom NV, a joint venture of Britain's General Electric Co Plc and France's Alcatel Alsthom.
